Are you under the impression that this longer quote makes McConnell look better than the oft-quoted part alone ("The single most important thing we want to achieve is for President Obama to be a one-term president")?

It actually makes him look worse - the one-term part looks just as bad, and the last sentence reveals him to be a liar, since the President did exactly that (meeting them significantly more than halfway, much to the annoyance of his liberal supporters) and the Republicans in Congress still utterly refused to work with him on anything, abusing the filibuster in historic fashion.

McConnell says: "...if he’s willing to meet us halfway on some of the biggest issues, it’s not inappropriate for us to do business with him."

Obama went more than halfway on the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), using concepts developed by the Heritage Foundation in the mid-80s as an alternative to single-payer health care, yet received virtually no Republican votes, even though several Republicans, including Sen. Bob Dole, had introduced legislation in Congress containing several components of what later became ACA.

McConnell was lying when he said he would be willing to work with Obama. We now know that Republican leaders met secretly prior to Obama's inauguration and agree not to cooperate with him.

Trouble is, when you've moved your position  to Nanjing, China, meeting you 'halfway,' puts you somewhere on the deepest part of the ocean floor.  They can't keep edging rightward then hold up the half-way promise and have it mean anything.

Well, for starters, we can read the most politicized quotes in their entirety, like this one from Mitch McConnell:

NATIONAL JOURNAL: You’ve been studying the history of presidents who lost part or all of Congress in their first term. Why?

McCONNELL: After 1994, the public had the impression we Republicans overpromised and underdelivered. We suffered from some degree of hubris and acted as if the president was irrelevant and we would roll over him. By the summer of 1995, he was already on the way to being reelected, and we were hanging on for our lives.

2010

George Bush was responsible for 9/11 then was he by this logic.....he was the top man when it happened so he must have been. Of course real life outside political partisanship is a bit more complicated than this.

The responsibility is that of the top man, Eric Holder. T^he "buck stops with him". The continued refusal of Holder and the White House to release all the emails only further emphasizes that Holder bears full responsibility and should be held in contempt of Congress and investigated for perjury.

Your claim that your observations are not political really don't convince me - though only you know your motivations so I don't want to make assumptions.

Actually, you are making suppositions and assumptions without having the evidence in front of you. You don't know what the Attny. General would have done. You don't know what he knew. You don't know who did what.

It is certainly conceivable for a local office to use tactics not approved by the main office in pursuit of an objective that WAS approved.

Have you never heard of the proverb: "Success has many fathers, failure is an orphan."?

The head of any large, multi-faceted operation, whether it is a government agency, a corporation or a bank, cannot know everything that happens, every minute of every day. He or she must rely on subordinates, who, in turn, rely on subordinates and policies and programs. The law recognizes this notion of reliance. If the reliance is reasonable, i.e. no warning flags, proper policies and procedures, the heads of large agencies, banks, and corporations are not legally responsible. It is this notion of reasonable reliance that helps to protect Presidents, CEO's and agency heads and even their top subordinates from legal liability.

This protection is not absolute. If the reliance was not reasonable - eg. the head had reason to suspect subordinates of gross incompetence, or had reason to suspect (by internal audits, for example) that policies and procedures were not followed or were inadequate, then the CEO, President or agency head should be brought to task.

This protection is necessary. Otherwise no one in their right mind would want to serve in such position and expose theselves to such liaibility.

No, common sense does not say that strains credibility.

You are probably right, the AG would have taken at least partial credit had the program worked. That being said, that doesn't mean he would have heard of it while the program was going on. There is a good chance he wouldn't have known until after it had been successful.

Those at the top of any organization (not just government) are flooded with information and have tons to deal with. Consequently they're not aware of every single program (or perhaps even the majority of them). Or even if they are, they certainly don't know the current status of each one. It makes complete sense that Holder didn't find out simply because his DAG didn't pass info on Fast and Furious onto him. I'm guessing the vast majority of info Holder gets (and any head of a government department) is via his chief of staff and DAGs, especially when it is a program in an agency like the ATF (or FBI or some other component in DOJ).

So, forgetting politics for the moment, we have a report that says that the local office (Phoenix) messed up badly and that they were further enabled by some mid-ranking types in the DOJ. My problem with this assessment is that IF all had gone well the AG would have taken full credit for the win and held some press conferences proclaiming the victory.

But, it didn't go well and now we have a report claiming that this was, essentially, a rogue operation that never reached the ears of the top levels of the DOJ until it went south. Common sense says this strains credibility at best and is a whitewash at worst. IF Mr. Holder did not know then he very well should have - it is his job to know about what's going on. If this had gone well would he have later said he knew nothing about while holding his press conference.

Again, this isn't a political view - just a pragmatic one that indicates this report is, at best, blowing smoke up our keesters. If you're going to do revisionist history at least do a better job of it and don't insult my intelligence. Dumb and dumber.

Well said Sir.  This man is truly out to rule not represent.

I have watched Romney destroy the American Promise he promised to save! The Declaration of Independence, the founding document of the intent of government, with "a decent respect" for human commmunity, lay a "foundation on such principles" as effect the "Happiness, Safety, and Prudence" and declares government not be "changed for transient causes." What Romney seeks to restore is a non-apologetic, blind indifference, the amoral mantle of success colonial planters of rice and tobacco wore--at a time when wealth and power knew no limit.

His program without principles is a raw, ugly breach of that promise and its "inelegant" destruction. Asked (6:53. 2nd video) would he "clean house," he replies, he "wishes" he could go "deeper." "Deeper." It is the most specific detail he has shared from his wish list of actions and policies. Ever more abstract, he rejects "redistribution," the latest conversative gloss of mischaracter that disrepects the long, careful debates, the hard won march forward, the beckoning progress that made the American Promise a pledge of excellence, opportunity, and liberty for the world.

His only policy, by his own admission, is a "tax cut." Not much traction, by his own admission, for a nation who demands a leader, not a balance sheet reader; a nation whose "Safety and Prudence" is measured by more than a single wretched, wrong note of a non-working, secret plan. Debts, deficits? The tax loop holes of corporate people? Victory, power first.

Today on CNBC, upon which I just happened to land, was doing a segment about The Most Expensive... you name it. Of course I lingered. There was the usual $100+ million-dollar mansion, New York apartment, yacht, but the $65,000 PUDDING purchased and eaten by a man trying to cheer himself up after some woman (girlfriend) left him. He said it took 15 minutes to eat but he'll remember the flavor forever. I know I'll never forget. Even one of the 'hosts' was visibly shocked.

We are truly at a crossroads in the history of our country and I think, the world. How is this going to end?

p.s. ..."low cunning of elites with clean soft hands..." was a real winner! Pink and soft.

I think it's a mistake to pile on poor Mr. Romney. Even though his father was on public relief as a child, Mitt has never learned the first lesson of American self-sufficiency. His wealth derives largely from looting other people's pensions, after all. He and those like him are the true freeloaders. They say, "You work and make bread, and we'll eat it." How much does Exxon, with 40 billion in profits, pay in taxes? Or Bank of America? Not one red cent. In fact, they get refunds of hundreds of millions on top of their profits and the taxes they don't pay. The problem with piling on Romney is it ignores the real disease sapping America's strength and foreshortening our future: we're top-heavy and oscillating from port to starboard on the verge of capsizing because those who do the real work of America, those who give our money value and protect that value, are hammered mercilessly by the low cunning of elites with clean, soft hands. We set out to erase aristocracy here, but the old nobility of leisure and affluence won't go quietly. The people who built America and defended it are homeless and the aristocracy fattens on the prostrate body. Mitt and his ilk don't dare face that fact.
Getting a little defensive, aren't we?
